_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FARMERS GRAIN CO.
P.O. BOX 69
STEPHEN, MN  56757

FOR FUTHER INFORMATION CONTACT TIM KUZNIA, PLANT MANAGER, 218-478-2258

1. THE FACILITY POLICY

THE, OWNERS, MANAGEMENT, AND EMPLOYEES OF FARMERS GRAIN CO. ARE
COMMITTED TO THE PREVENTION OF ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.
IF AN ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SHOULD OCCUR, THE FACILITY IS PREPARED TO WORK WITH THE 
LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT, OR OTHER AUTHORITIES, TO MITIGATE ANY RELEASE AND MINIMIZE
THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE TO PEOPLE AND THE ENVIRONMENT.


2. FACILITY INFORMATION

 THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY AT THE FACILITY IS THE STORAGE  AND BLENDING OF FERTILIZERS FOR
SALE TO FARMERS.
 
 ANDYDROUS AMMONIA IS RECEIVED, STORED AND DISTRIBUTED FOR DIRECT APPLICATION.
ANHYROUS AMMONIA IS USED FOR CROP PRODUCTION NUTRIENTS.

 THE MAXIMUM QUANTITY OF AMMONIA STORED WOULD BE 240,000 POUNDS IN OUR
18,000 GALLON STORAGE TANK AND NURSE TANKS. THE MAXIMUM HANDLED WOULD BE
THE UNLOADING OF A TANK TRUCK HOLDING 40,000 POUNDS.

3. THE WORST-CASE RELEASED SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO.

 A. THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO FOR ANHYDROUS AMMONIA WOULD BE THE RELEASE OF
THE TOTAL CONTENTS OF A STORAGE TANK RELEASED AS A GAS OVER TEN MINUTES. THE
MAXIMUM QUANTITY RELEASED WOULD BE 80,000 POUNDS, WHICH REPRESENTS THE VOLUME
OF THE STORAGE TANK AT 85% CAPACITY AS LIMITED BY DESIGN STANDARDS. THE DISTANCE
THE ENDPOINT (POINT OF DISPERSION TO 200 PPM) IS .94 MILES.

 B. THE ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO FOR ANHYDROUS AMMONIA BASED ON THE HAZARD
REVIEW IS A 2 MINUTE RELEASE FROM A BREAK IN A 2 INCH PIPE. THE DISTANCE TO THE 
ENDPOINT (POINT OF DISPERSION TO 200 PPM) IS .56 MILES.

4. THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.

 THE FACILITY HAS IMPLEMENTED THE PROVISIONS OF "SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE
STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA, K-61.1", PUBLISHED BY THE AMERICAN
NATIONAL STANDARDS INSTITUTE, INC. AND STANDARDS OF THE U.S. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY
AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "STORAGE AND HANDLING O

F
ANDHYROUS AMMONIA". IN ADDITION, MINNESOTA DEPT. OF AG RULES.

 5. THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.

 A.THERE HAS BEEN NO ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IN THE PAST
FIVE YEARS THAT:
  HAVE CAUSED ANY DEATHS, INJURIES, OR SIGNIFICANT PROPERTY DAMAGE AT THE FACILITY;
NOR TO OUR KNOWLEDGE, HAVE RESULTED IN OFF SITE DEATHS, INJURIES, EVACUATIONS,
SHELTERING IN PLACE, PROPERTY DAMAGE OR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE.

6. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.

   THE FACILITY HAS;

 A. A WRITTEN EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OSHA STANDARD, 29 CFR
1910.38;

 B. PROVIDED STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES THE EMERGENCY PLANNING AND THE COMMUNITY
RIGHT-TO-KNOW INFORMATION AS REQUIRED UNDER SARA TITLE III (EPCRA).
 

 C. COORINATED WITH LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS.

 7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

 SAFETY IMPROVEMENT IS AN ON-GOING PROCESS AT THE FACILITY. PERIODIC EVALUATIONS
ARE PREFORMED TO ASSESS THE MAINTENANCE OF SAFE CONDITIONS. THERE ARE NO ADDITIONAL
SPECIFIC ANHYDROUS AMMONIA SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION AT THIS
TIME.
